title: Why are portable game consoles dying out? - Quora

response.answer_text: You are missing the most important portable gaming console there is. Sure, playstation 4 has sold 100 million units or something like that, but that is a drop in the bucket… Portable gaming has never been more popular. More Than 2.4 Billion People Will Play Mobile Games This Year, According To Analyst And sure, these games are not as powerful/complex as some of the others, but they are getting there. You can play Call of Duty on your phone, DOTA, and a bunch of other things. Old console games are available to be downloaded onto your phone like sonic and etc. All of these games can even be played with offline, online by yourself, or online with friends or complete strangers all over the world. Phones even have the capability to play virtual reality and augmented reality games, both solo and with others. AND the big thing here… For all of these apps… They are essentially cross-platform. It doesn’t matter if you have an awesome android, stupid apple, or anything else. You are not limited from playing these games with your friends based on what phones they have… I think the best way I heard it put was by Flash Gitz… Consoles will always have a place in gaming, but ease of use is becoming a very big commodity. No discs. No four hour installs. Upgrading “consoles” every couple/few years when you replace your phone anyway…

I don’t think they are. Nintendo 3DS and 2DS are still strong sellers and the record sales figures for the Switch indicate that there’s still a great demand for portable gaming. Sony’s portable consoles are failing but this has little to do with smartphones, it’s a combination of Sony handling their devices poorly and pitting them against a well supported competitor. It might not seem worthwhile to someone who only plays mobile games but for gamers familiar with portable consoles, the quality of the content is worth the bother of carrying an extra device, the two mediums don’t compare, the only similarity they have is that they both run on devices that fit in your pocket. The success of Nintendo’s portable and hybrid platforms shows that the portable market isn’t impacted that strongly by the introduction of mobile gaming.
